After gravitational compression, the Moon's glowing, hot surface cooled and cracked.  Large and small rocks continued to fall onto the lunar surface, including a massive meteorite that formed the Aitken Basin about 4.3 billion years ago. This period of intense meteorite bombardment lasted for hundreds of millions of years, during which time vast basins appeared across the entire surface of the Moon.  Over the next several billion years, lava flows flowed on the side facing Earth, forming the lunar maria we know today. These continued meteorite impacts, which have subsided slightly over the last billion years, formed the craters we see today.
